item.description:
here is some markdown

cool

  • list item
  • another

Assignment 1.4: Data Types and Operators Practice

Unit 1, Lesson 4 - PREPARE Assignment Due: Next class period Submission Format: Screenshots of your Python code and output

Part A: Data Type Exploration (25 points)

Create and test variables of each data type.

Task 1: Create Variables

Write and run this program:

# Integer variables
my_age = 16  # Replace with your actual age
favorite_number = 7  # Replace with your favorite number
negative_temp = -10

# Float variables  
my_height = 5.5  # Replace with your height in feet
price_of_gas = 3.89
pi_value = 3.14159

# String variables
my_name = "Your Name"  # Replace with your actual name
favorite_song = "Song Title"  # Replace with your favorite song
pet_name = "Pet Name"  # Replace with a pet's name

# Test the types
print("Age:", my_age, "Type:", type(my_age))
print("Height:", my_height, "Type:", type(my_height))
print("Name:", my_name, "Type:", type(my_name))
print("Song:", favorite_song, "Type:", type(favorite_song))

Screenshot 1: Show your code and the output from running this program.

Assignment 1.7 (Prepare): Operators and Type Casting Practice

PCEP 1.4 - Choose operators and data types adequate to the problem

Assignment Overview

This assignment reinforces your understanding of Python operators, operator precedence, and type casting through hands-on practice problems that mirror PCEP exam questions.

Learning Objectives

By completing this assignment, you will:

  • Apply all Python operator types correctly
  • Solve operator precedence problems
  • Perform type casting operations
  • Choose appropriate data types for different scenarios
  • Debug common operator-related errors

Part 1: Operator Precedence Puzzles (25 points)

Instructions: Solve each expression by hand first, showing your work step-by-step using operator precedence rules. Then verify your answers using Python.

Assignment 1.8: Unit 1 Assessment - Interactive Python Console Application

Type: PERFORM | Due: End of Week 2 | Points: 100

Overview

Create a comprehensive interactive console application that demonstrates mastery of all PCEP Section 1 objectives. Your program should be engaging, user-friendly, and showcase proper Python programming practices.

PCEP Section 1 Objectives Demonstrated

Your project must clearly demonstrate ALL of the following PCEP-30-02 Section 1 objectives:

PCEP 1.1 - Fundamental Terms and Definitions

  • Use Python as an interpreted language (no compilation step needed)
  • Demonstrate understanding of proper Python syntax and semantics
  • Include comments explaining your code’s lexical elements

PCEP 1.2 - Python Logic and Structure

  • Use Python keywords appropriately
  • Implement proper indentation for code blocks
  • Include meaningful comments throughout your code

PCEP 1.3 - Literals and Variables

  • Use Boolean, integer, floating-point, and string literals
  • Demonstrate at least 2 different numeral systems (binary, octal, hex)
  • Create variables following PEP-8 naming conventions
  • Use scientific notation where appropriate

PCEP 1.4 - Operators and Data Types

  • Use arithmetic operators: **, *, /, %, //, +, −
  • Use string operators: *, +
  • Use assignment and shortcut operators
  • Demonstrate operator precedence understanding
  • Use Boolean operators: not, and, or
  • Use relational operators: ==, !=, >, >=, <, <=
  • Include type casting operations

PCEP 1.5 - Input/Output Operations

  • Use print() function with sep and end parameters
  • Use input() function for user interaction
  • Combine input with type conversion

Project Options

Choose ONE of the following project types:

Lesson 1.9: Project Work Session Activity Guide

Assignment 1.8 Completion Day | 50-minute class period

Class Period Structure

Opening (5 minutes)

Objectives Review and Status Check

  • Quick review of PCEP Section 1 objectives
  • Student status check (show of hands for progress level)
  • Clarify any remaining questions about requirements

Troubleshooting Mini-Lesson (10 minutes)

Common Issues Prevention

  • Review most frequent coding errors from Unit 1
  • Live demonstration of debugging techniques
  • Q&A for any conceptual confusion

Work Session 1 (15 minutes)

Individual Coding Time

Assignment 2.6 – Prepare

Goal: Practice writing for loops with ranges and sequences.

Part 1: Predict the Output

for i in range(3):
    print("Hello")

Part 2: Debugging

Fix this code so it prints the numbers 1 to 5:

for i in range(1, 5):
print(i)

Part 3: Write Your Own

  1. Write a for loop that prints the numbers 1 through 10.

  2. Write a for loop that prints the letters of your name, one per line.

Assignment 2.8 – Prepare (Review)

Goal: Practice combining while loops, for loops, and if statements. Approx. 10 problems.

Problem 1

Write a program that prints the numbers 1 through 10 using a for loop.

Problem 2

Write a program that prints the numbers 10 down to 1 using a while loop.

Problem 3

Write a program that asks the user for a number and prints whether it is even or odd using an if statement.

Python 1 – Unit 3: Data Structures (2 Weeks)

Scope

  • Lists: creation, indexing, slicing, methods
  • Tuples: immutability, unpacking
  • Dictionaries: key-value pairs, iteration, lookups
  • Basic operations: membership, iteration, adding/removing elements
  • Real-world applications and practice problems

Daily Breakdown

Week 1

Day 1 (Lesson 3.1) – Lists: Basics

  • Creating lists, indexing, modifying elements.
  • Assignment 3.1: simple practice with creating/modifying lists.

Day 2 (Lesson 3.2) – Lists: Slicing & Methods

  • Slicing, append, insert, remove, pop, len.
  • Assignment 3.2: list slicing challenges.

Day 3 (Lesson 3.3) – Lists: Iteration

Unit 4: Functions and Exceptions

Overview

  • Duration: ~10 lessons (2 weeks)
  • Focus: Writing reusable functions and handling errors with exceptions.
  • Goal: By the end of this unit, you will be able to write testable functions, pass information with parameters, and handle errors gracefully.

Lessons

Lesson 4.1 – Intro to Functions

  • What functions are and why we use them
  • Defining functions with def
  • Writing and calling simple functions

Lesson 4.2 – Function Parameters

  • Positional, keyword, and default parameters
  • Variable-length parameters: *args and **kwargs
  • Writing functions that avoid side effects

Lesson 4.3 – Return Values vs. Side Effects

  • Returning values from functions
  • Returning multiple values
  • Why returning is better than printing (testability)

Lesson 4.4 – Scope and Lifetime

  • Local vs. global variables
  • Why globals are risky
  • How variable scope affects functions

Lesson 4.5 – Errors and Exceptions

  • Common runtime errors (ZeroDivisionError, ValueError, IndexError)
  • Why programs crash without handling errors

Lesson 4.6 – Handling Exceptions

  • try/except blocks
  • Catching specific vs. general exceptions
  • Preventing program crashes

Lesson 4.7 – Raising Exceptions

  • Using raise to trigger errors
  • Validating inputs
  • Making your code more predictable

Lesson 4.8 – Functions + Exceptions Together

  • Combining functions with error handling
  • Example: safe division, safe file opening
  • Writing robust programs

Lesson 4.9 – Review & Rehearse

  • Quiz
  • Debugging activity: “Name That Error”
  • Review games

Lesson 4.10 – Perform (Exam)

  • Exam: Functions and Exceptions
  • Show what you can do independently

By the end of Unit 4, you will be able to:

  • Define and call your own functions
  • Use different types of parameters
  • Write functions without side effects
  • Handle exceptions with try, except, and raise
  • Build programs that are robust and testable

Assignment 4.1 — Tiny Functions

Category: prepare

Overview

Write three small, pure functions and verify their behavior with simple tests. Focus on returning values (not printing inside the functions).

Tasks

  1. square(n) → int
  • Return n squared. Assume n is an integer.
  1. is_even(n) → bool
  • Return True if n is even, else False.
  1. greet(name) → str
  • Return a greeting string like "Hello, Ada!" (do not print inside).
  1. Test Calls
  • print example calls and expected results.
  • Include at least 2 test cases per function.

What To Submit

  • File: assignment_4_1.py
  • Ensure the script runs without errors and prints your test outputs.
  • Keep lines ≤ 100 chars where practical. Follow PEP 8 for names/spacing.

Rubric (10 points)

  • Correct function behavior: 6 points (2 per function)
  • Test coverage: 2 points (≥2 cases per function, printed)
  • Code quality: 2 points (clear names, docstrings, no extra prints in functions)

Hints

  • Return values from functions; do not print inside the core logic.
  • Keep your tests outside functions in the __main__ guard.
  • Prefer small, descriptive names and one responsibility per function.

Assignment 4.2: Function Parameters

Prepare

  1. Review the lesson slides on function parameters.
  2. Re-read the Python Essentials section on functions with parameters.

Practice

Part A: Positional & Keyword Parameters

  1. Write a function rectangle_area(length, width) that returns the area.
    • Call it once with positional arguments.
    • Call it again using keyword arguments.

Part B: Default Parameters

  1. Write a function introduce(name, hobby="reading") that returns a sentence like: "My name is Alex and I enjoy reading."

Part C: Variable-Length Parameters

  1. Write a function multiply_all(*nums) that multiplies any number of inputs together.

🕹️ Unit 5: Games with Python (Oct 20–31)

Week 1: Oct 20–24

Focus: Core mechanics of text-based games (strings, loops, conditionals, lists)

Mon Oct 20 – Intro to Games in Python

  • Objective: Recall PCEP concepts inside a new “game” frame (input, random, print formatting).
  • In-class: Demo number guessing game. Students tweak parameters.
  • Assignment 5.1 (Prepare, graded): Short coding warm-up — modify number guessing to allow 5 tries.

Tue Oct 21 – Hangman Pt. 1

  • Objective: Use loops, lists, and conditionals for a word game.
  • In-class: Build scaffold for Hangman (choose word, display blanks).
  • Assignment 5.2 (Prepare, not graded): Practice — write function to check if a guessed letter is in the word.

Wed Oct 22 – Hangman Pt. 2

  • Objective: Add error handling (try/except) for invalid inputs.
  • In-class: Play full Hangman as class. Debug together.
  • Assignment 5.3 (Prepare, graded): Submit working Hangman with error handling.

Thu Oct 23 – Debugging Game Bugs

  • Objective: Strengthen debugging and tracing.
  • In-class: Teacher provides buggy versions of Hangman; students fix them.
  • Assignment 5.4 (Rehearse, graded): Debugging Lab (graded for accuracy + explanation of fixes).

Fri Oct 24 – Mini-Challenges

  • Objective: Apply learned mechanics in small code snippets.
  • In-class: Timed coding “game jam” — who can finish small tasks fastest?
  • Assignment 5.5 (Prepare, not graded): Write a “Guess the Word” snippet with pre-set answers.

Week 2: Oct 27–31

Focus: Larger projects, functions, group coding, assessment

Assignment 5.1: Number Guessing Game (Prepare)

Goal

Modify the number guessing game we wrote in class to allow 5 tries instead of just 1.

Instructions

  1. Copy the number guessing code from today’s slides.
  2. Add a loop so the player gets 5 attempts to guess the number.
  3. If the player guesses correctly, print a winning message and end the game immediately.
  4. If the player uses all 5 tries without success, print "You lost! The number was X".
  5. Submit your .py file in Canvas.

Example Run

Guess a number 1–10: 5
Wrong!
Guess a number 1–10: 7
Wrong!
Guess a number 1–10: 9
Correct!

Rubric

  • Uses a loop for 5 tries (40%)
  • Ends early if the player guesses correctly (30%)
  • Shows losing message if no correct guess (20%)
  • Code runs without errors (10%)

Assignment 7.1: ASCII Art Pyramid (Prepare)

Goal

Write a Python program that generates ASCII art pyramids using user input.

Instructions

  1. Ask the user to enter a character (e.g., *, #, @).
  2. Ask the user to enter a height (an integer).
  3. Use a loop to print a pyramid with that character and height.

Example Run

Enter a character: *
Enter a height: 4

*
**
***
****

Challenge

  • Allow the user to choose between a normal pyramid and an upside-down pyramid.
  • Print both versions.

Submission

Upload your .py file to Canvas.

Assignment 7.4: Debugging Your Chatbot (Rehearse)

Goal

Strengthen your debugging skills by finding and fixing common chatbot errors.

Instructions

  1. Take your chatbot from Assignment 7.3.
  2. Introduce at least 2 intentional bugs (e.g., missing condition, case sensitivity, logic error).
  3. Swap code with a partner and debug their chatbot.
  4. Fix the bugs and write a short explanation of what you changed.

Example Bug

Buggy Code:

response = input("Do you like cats?")
if response == "yes":
    print("Cats are great!")
# forgot elif for "no"

Fixed Code:

Assignment 7.12: Catch-Up & Refinement Checkpoint (Prepare)

Goal

Complete any unfinished assignments and refine your Creative Project in preparation for final presentations.

Instructions

  1. Review your work from Unit 7 (Assignments 7.1–7.11).
    • Complete or revise any missing assignments.
  2. Open your Creative Project and refine it by:
    • Adding clear menus, instructions, and comments
    • Improving formatting and output readability
    • Debugging any remaining errors
  3. Add at least one “quality of life” feature to your project, such as:
    • Replay option
    • Help menu
    • Cleaner spacing or formatting
  4. Submit your updated .py file and any completed catch-up work to Canvas.

Example Improvements

  • Added a help() function that explains the program
  • Fixed spacing with "\n" for better readability
  • Added a replay loop so users don’t need to restart the program

Rubric

  • All Unit 7 assignments complete or caught up (30%)
  • Project refined with clear instructions and comments (30%)
  • At least one new quality-of-life feature added (30%)
  • Submission is complete and error-free (10%)

Assignment 7.13: Capstone Project Work Day Checkpoint (Prepare)

Goal

Show progress on your Creative Project by adding new features or improvements.

Instructions

  1. Open your current project code.
  2. Make at least one major improvement based on peer or teacher feedback. Examples:
    • Fixing a bug
    • Adding a new feature
    • Improving menus or instructions
  3. Test your project to make sure the new feature works correctly.
  4. Save your progress and submit your updated .py file to Canvas.

Example Improvements

  • Added replay loop so the program can run multiple times without restarting
  • Added new responses to a chatbot
  • Improved ASCII art formatting
  • Added scoring or a simple leaderboard

Challenge

  • Add one “wow factor” feature that makes your project stand out (e.g., random Easter egg, extra storyline branch, bonus mode).

Rubric

  • At least one major improvement added (40%)
  • Project runs without errors (30%)
  • Code includes clear comments for new changes (20%)
  • Extra creativity/wow factor feature (10%)

Assignment 7.14: Practice Presentation Reflection (Prepare)

Goal

Rehearse your project presentation and reflect on feedback received.

Instructions

  1. Present your Creative Project to a small group of classmates.
  2. During your presentation, make sure you:
    • Introduce your project idea
    • Demonstrate at least one working feature
    • Highlight one piece of code and explain it
  3. After your group presentation, write a short reflection (1–2 paragraphs) answering:
    • What part of your presentation went well?
    • What feedback did you receive?
    • What changes will you make for your final presentation?

Example Reflection

“I felt confident showing how my chatbot uses if/elif/else to respond to different inputs. My classmates said I should slow down when explaining the code and add more comments to make it clearer. For the final presentation, I’ll include more pauses and add comments to my code before presenting.”

Assignment 7.16: Final Presentation – Part 2 (Perform)

Goal

Present your Creative Project to the class and demonstrate your coding skills.

Instructions

  1. Prepare a 3–5 minute presentation of your project.
  2. Your presentation must include:
    • Introduction of your project idea
    • Live demonstration of your program running
    • Highlight of 2–3 code features (loops, functions, conditionals, input handling, etc.)
    • Explanation of at least one challenge you overcame
  3. Be ready to answer 1–2 questions from the audience or teacher.

Example Flow

  • Intro: “My project is a quiz game that asks fun questions and keeps score.”
  • Demo: Run the program and show sample output.
  • Code Highlight: Show how a loop keeps the game running until the user exits.
  • Challenge: “I had to fix a bug where the score didn’t update. I solved it by moving the variable inside the loop.”

Submission

No file upload required — grade based on live presentation. Teacher will use rubric below.

Assignment 7.17: Reflection Journal (Prepare)

Goal

Reflect on your learning journey in Python this semester and set goals for the future.

Instructions

  1. Write a short reflection (1–2 paragraphs) that answers:
    • What was your favorite project or assignment this semester, and why?
    • What was the hardest challenge you faced, and how did you overcome it?
    • How has your confidence with Python changed since the beginning of the course?
    • What is one goal you have for yourself in coding next semester?
  2. Be honest and specific — this reflection is about your personal growth.
  3. Submit your reflection to Canvas.

Example Reflection

“My favorite project was the random story generator because I could make funny results. The hardest part was debugging my chatbot when it kept crashing, but I learned to use print() to trace errors. At the start of the semester, I didn’t know how to use loops, but now I can make full programs with functions and conditionals. Next semester, I want to learn how to use Python with real data sets.”

item.title: Assignment 1.1
item.description:
Assignment 1.1 (Prepare): Programming Concepts and Python Setup

Category: Prepare

Part 1: Programming Concepts Vocabulary (10 points)

Complete the following definitions in your own words. Use the course materials and additional research as needed.

  1. Algorithm: Your definition here

  2. Program: Your definition here

  3. Compiler: Your definition here

  4. Interpreter: Your definition here

  5. Source Code: Your definition here

  6. Machine Code: Your definition here

  7. Lexis: Your definition here

  8. Syntax: Your definition here

  9. Semantics: Your definition here

item.title: Assignment 1.2
item.description:
Assignment 1.2: Syntax Error Detective

Due: Thursday, August 15 (before class) Type: Prepare Points: 20

Overview

Practice identifying and fixing syntax errors while understanding the difference between syntax and semantic issues in Python code. This assignment reinforces PCEP 1.1 objectives on Python’s lexis, syntax, and semantics.

Part 1: Syntax Error Hunt (10 points)

Each code sample below contains exactly one syntax error. Your job is to:

  1. Identify the error
  2. Explain what’s wrong
  3. Provide the corrected code
  4. Test your fix in Python to make sure it works

Sample Format:

Original Code: print "Hello World"
Error: Missing parentheses around the argument
Corrected Code: print("Hello World")
Tested: ✓ (checkmark when you've tested it)

Code Samples to Fix:

1.

item.title: Assignment 1.3
item.description:
Assignment 1.3:

Unit 1, Lesson 1 - PREPARE Assignment Due: Next class period

Setup Instructions

  1. Open your Python interpreter (type python in Command Prompt/Terminal)
  2. You should see the >>> prompt
  3. Type each program exactly as shown
  4. Take screenshots or write down what happens

Program 1: Personal Introduction (15 points)

Type this program and run it:

print("Hi there!")
print("My name is [YOUR ACTUAL NAME]")
print("I am learning Python programming")

Replace [YOUR ACTUAL NAME] with your real name

item.title: Assignment 1.5
item.description:
Assignment 1.5 – Boolean Logic

Goal: Practice writing and testing boolean expressions.

Instructions:

  1. Write a Python program called boolean_quiz.py.
  2. Your program should:
    • Ask the user to enter two numbers (use input() and int() to convert).
    • Print out the results of the following checks:
      1. Is the first number greater than the second?
      2. Are the two numbers equal?
      3. Is at least one number greater than 10?
      4. Is the first number NOT zero?
    • Each result should print as True or False.

Example Run:

item.title: Assignment 1.6
item.description:
1. Problem 1: Boolean Logic Check

    • Ask the user for two boolean values (True or False).

    • Combine them using and and print the result.

      • Example:

        • Input: True, False
        • Output: False

  2. Problem 2: Odd/Even Check

    • Ask the user for a number.

    • Use boolean logic to check if the number is even.

      • Hint: You can check if number % 2 == 0 using boolean logic.

      • Example:

        • Input: 4
        • Output: True (even)

  3. Problem 3: True/False Assignment

item.title: Assignment 2.2
item.description:
Assignment 2.2 – Prepare

Goal: Practice using if … else with correct indentation.

Part 1: Predict the Output

What will Python print?

x = 4
if x > 10:
    print("Greater than 10")
else:
    print("10 or smaller")
print("Done")

Part 2: Debugging

Fix this code:

color = input("Enter a color: ")
if color == "red":
    print("Roses are red")
else:
    print("Nice color!")

Part 3: Write Your Own

  1. Ask the user for their age.
  • If age is 16 or older → print “You can drive!”
  • Else → print “Not yet!”
  1. Ask the user for a number.
  • If it’s divisible by 5 → print “Multiple of 5”
  • Else → print “Not a multiple of 5”

item.title: Assignment 2.3
item.description:
Assignment 2.3 – Prepare

Goal: Practice using elif to handle multiple conditions.

Part 1: Predict the Output

y = 7
if y > 10:
    print("More than 10")
elif y > 5:
    print("More than 5")
else:
    print("5 or less")

Part 2: Debugging

Fix this code so it runs correctly:

day = input("Enter a day: ")
if day == "Monday":
    print("Start of the week")
elif day == "Friday"
    print("Almost weekend!")
else:
    print("Midweek day")

Part 3: Write Your Own

  1. Ask the user for a number grade (0–100).
  • 90 or above → “A”
  • 80 or above → “B”
  • 70 or above → “C”
  • Else → “F”
  1. Ask the user for their age.
  • 0–12 → “Child”
  • 13–19 → “Teenager”
  • 20 or above → “Adult”

item.title: Assignment 2.4
item.description:
Assignment 2.4 – Prepare

Goal: Practice writing and controlling while loops.

Part 1: Predict the Output

x = 1
while x < 4:
    print(x)
    x = x + 1
print("Done")

Part 2: Debugging

Fix this code so it prints numbers 1 through 5:

count = 1
while count <= 5:
print(count)
count = count + 1

Part 3: Write Your Own

  1. Ask the user for a number.
  • While the number is less than 10, keep asking again.
  • When they finally enter 10 or more, print “Thanks!”
  1. Write a guessing game.
  • Set a secret number (like 7).
  • Keep asking the user to guess until they get it right.
  • Print “Correct!” when they do.
  1. Multiplication practice.
  • Ask the user a multiplication problem, like 3 * 4.
  • While they give the wrong answer, keep asking.
  • When they get it right, print “Well done!”
  1. Countdown timer.
  • Ask the user for a number n.
  • Use a while loop to count down from n to 1.
  • Print “Blast off!” at the end.
  1. Collecting names.
  • Keep asking the user to enter a name.
  • Stop only when they type “stop”.
  • After the loop ends, print all the names they entered.

item.title: Assignment 2.5
item.description:
Assignment 2.5 – Prepare

Goal: Practice nesting, while–else, break, and continue.

Part 1: Predict the Output

x = 3
while x > 0:
    if x % 2 == 0:
        print("even")
    else:
        print("odd")
    x = x - 1
else:
    print("done")

Part 2: Debugging

Fix this code so it stops correctly:

while True:
    name = input("Enter a name (or 'stop' to end): ")
    if name = "stop":
        break
    print("Hello", name)

Part 3: Write Your Own

  1. Password checker
  • Ask the user for a password until they type “letmein”
  • If they get it right, print “Welcome” and stop
  1. Skip multiples of 3
  • Use a loop from 1 to 10
  • Skip printing numbers that are multiples of 3 (use continue)
  1. Countdown with else
  • Start at 5 and count down to 1
  • Use while … else to print “Blast off!” when finished
  1. Nested logic
  • Keep asking the user for a number
  • If it’s even, print “even”
  • If it’s odd, print “odd”
  • Stop the loop if they enter a negative number
  1. Number collector
  • Keep asking the user for numbers until they type 0
  • Store all positive numbers in a list
  • After the loop, print the list

item.title: Assignment 2.7
item.description:
Assignment 2.7 – Prepare

Goal: Practice different for loop patterns without using lists.

Part 1: Predict the Output

for i in range(1, 10, 3):
    print(i)

Part 2: Debugging

Fix this code so it prints the numbers 1 through 5:

for i in range(1, 5):
print(i)

Part 3: Write Your Own

  1. Write a for loop that prints the numbers from 10 down to 1.

  2. Write a for loop that prints the multiples of 5 from 5 to 50.

item.title: Assignment 2.9
item.description:
Goal: More practice with if statements, while loops, and for loops.

Problem 1

Write a program that asks the user for a number and prints “Even” if it is divisible by 2, otherwise prints “Odd”.

Problem 2

Write a program that prints the numbers 5 through 15 using a for loop.

Problem 3

Write a program that counts down from 10 to 1 using a while loop, then prints “Done!”.

item.title: Assignment 3.1
item.description:
Assignment 3.1 (Prepare)

Instructions

Complete the following exercises to practice working with Python lists. Write your answers in a .py file or in your notebook.

Part A: Create and Access

  1. Create a list called animals with at least 4 animals of your choice.
  2. Print the first and last items in the list.
  3. Print the length of the list using len().

Part B: Modify

  1. Change the 2nd item in your list to a different animal.
  2. Add a new animal to the end of the list with .append().
  3. Remove one animal by its name using .remove().

Part C: Apply

  1. Create a list of 5 numbers.
  2. Print the 3rd number in the list.
  3. Replace the last number with 100.
  4. Add a new number at the end.
  5. Print the updated list.

Submission

Turn in your completed code file for review. Be sure your file runs without errors.

item.title: Assignment 3.10
item.description:
Assignment 3.10 – Mixed Practice with Data Structures

Objective

Practice combining lists, tuples, and dictionaries in simple programs.

Part A: Lists of Tuples

  1. Create a list of 3 tuples representing students: (name, age).
  2. Loop through and print each student’s name and age.

Part B: List of Dictionaries

  1. Make a list of 3 dictionaries, each representing a fruit with keys: name, color.
  2. Loop through the list and print each fruit in the format: Fruit: Color.

Part C: Dictionary of Lists

  1. Create a dictionary called grades with keys: math, science, and english.
  2. Each key should map to a list of 3 scores.
  3. Print the list of scores for science.

Part D: Mini Challenge

Write a program that:

item.title: Assignment 3.2
item.description:
Assignment 3.2 – List Slicing and Methods

Objective

Practice creating slices of lists and using common list methods.

Part A: Slicing

  1. Given the list:

    nums = [2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14]
    • Print the first 3 numbers.
    • Print everything from the 3rd element to the end.
    • Print the middle 3 numbers.

  2. What does this print?

    letters = ["a", "b", "c", "d", "e", "f"]
print(letters[1:5])

Part B: Methods

  1. Start with the list:

    fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]

    Do the following:

    • Append “orange”
    • Insert “grape” at index 1
    • Remove “banana”
    • Pop the last element
    • Print the final list

  2. Write code that:

item.title: Assignment 3.3
item.description:
Assignment 3.3 – Looping Through Lists

Objective

Practice using for loops and membership checks with lists.

Part A: Basic Loops

  1. Write a program that creates a list of 5 favorite foods and prints them one by one.
  2. Create a list of numbers [2, 4, 6, 8, 10]. Use a loop to print each number doubled.

Part B: Using Indexes

  1. Given this list: 
    animals = ["cat", "dog", "fish"]
    Write a loop that prints: 
    0 cat
1 dog
2 fish

Part C: Membership

  1. Make a list of colors. Ask the user to type a color. If it’s in the list, print “Found it!”, otherwise print “Not here.”
  2. Why might checking membership be useful in a game?

Part D: Mini Challenge

Write a program that:

item.title: Assignment 3.4
item.description:
Assignment 3.4 – Working with Tuples

Objective

Understand how tuples work and practice using packing, unpacking, and immutability.

Part A: Basics

  1. Create a tuple with 3 numbers. Print the second number.
  2. Try to change one element of the tuple. What happens?

Part B: Packing & Unpacking

  1. Pack your first name and last name into a tuple called person.
  2. Unpack person into two variables and print them.

### Part C: Returning Tuples 1. Write a function first_and_last(lst) that returns a tuple with the first and last elements of a list. 2. Call the function on [10, 20, 30, 40] and unpack the result into two variables.

item.title: Assignment 3.5
item.description:
Assignment 3.5 – Dictionary Basics

Objective

Learn how to create, access, add, and remove items from dictionaries.

Part A: Creating and Accessing

  1. Create a dictionary called car with keys: make, model, year.

    • Print the model.

  2. Add a new key color with any value.

    • Print the full dictionary.

Part B: Modifying and Removing

  1. Start with this dictionary: 
    movie = {"title": "Inception", "year": 2010}
    • Change the year to 2012
    • Add a key rating with a value of 9
    • Remove the title key
    • Print the result

Part C: Membership

  1. Create a dictionary student with keys: name, age, grade.
  2. Write code that checks if age is in the dictionary. If yes, print the value.

Part D: Mini Challenge

  1. Write a program that:

item.title: Assignment 3.6
item.description:
Assignment 3.6 – Dictionary Iteration & Methods

Objective

Practice looping through dictionaries and using built-in dictionary methods.

Part A: Iteration

  1. Create a dictionary states with 3 states and their capitals.
    • Loop through keys and print them.
    • Loop through values and print them.
    • Loop through both key and value to print State -> Capital.

Part B: get()

  1. Given: 
    student = {"name": "Bob", "grade": "11th"}
    • Use get() to safely print the student’s age with a default message.

Part C: update()

  1. Start with: 
    car = {"make": "Toyota", "model": "Camry"}
    • Use update() to add the year and change the model.
    • Print the dictionary.

Part D: del

  1. Create a dictionary book with keys: title, author, year.
  2. Delete the year key and print the result.

Part E: Mini Challenge

Write a program that:

item.title: Assignment 3.7
item.description:
Assignment 3.7 — List Comprehensions Drills

Overview

Practice mapping and filtering with Python list comprehensions. Complete the tasks below in a single script named assignment_3_7.py. Unless specified otherwise, solve using list comprehensions (no explicit for loops for the core result).

Tasks

  1. Squares 1..20
  • Build a list of squares for numbers 1 through 20 (inclusive).
  • Variable name: squares_1_20.
  • Example: first five are [1, 4, 9, 16, 25].
  1. Keep Evens, Double Them
  • Given nums = [3, 8, 11, 14, 2, 7], produce [16, 28, 4].
  • Filter even numbers, then map by doubling.
  • Variable name: doubled_evens.
  1. Clean Names
  • Given names = [' ALIce', 'bob ', ' ', 'Eve'], build ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Eve'].
  • Strip whitespace and title-case, skip blanks.
  • One comprehension. Variable: clean_names.

Optional Extra Challenges

  1. Flatten One Level
  • Given matrix = [[1, 2], [3, 4, 5], [6]], build [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6].
  • Use a nested comprehension. Variable: flat.
  1. Words ≥ 5 Letters (Lowercased)
  • Given text = 'Time flies like an arrow; fruit flies like a banana.'
  • Split on whitespace, strip leading/trailing punctuation ,.;:!? from each token, keep words with length ≥ 5, and lowercase them.
  • Example output (order matters): ['flies', 'arrow', 'fruit', 'flies', 'banana'].
  • Variable: long_words.

item.title: Assignment 3.9
item.description:
Assignment 3.9 – Operating with Strings

Objective

Practice constructing, slicing, and modifying strings using functions and methods.

Part A: Basics

  1. Create a string with your favorite food.
  2. Print the first character and the last character.
  3. Print the string sliced from index 1 to 4.

Part B: Escape Characters & Quoting

  1. Write a string that contains both single and double quotes.
  2. Write a string with a newline character (\n) and print it.

Part C: Multi-line Strings

  1. Create a multi-line string with two lines of text (like a poem or song lyric).
  2. Print it.

Part D: Functions & Methods

  1. Create the string language = "Python".

item.title: Assignment 4.3
item.description:
Assignment 4.3: Scope

Prepare

  1. Review Lesson 4.3 slides.
  2. Revisit Python Essentials on local vs. global variables.

Practice

Part A: Local Scope

  1. Write a function make_local() that creates a variable x = 10 inside the function and returns it.
    • Try printing x outside the function. What happens?

Part B: Global Scope

  1. Create a global variable school = "Berry".
    • Write a function get_school() that returns school.
    • Call the function and print the result.

Part C: Shadowing

  1. Write a global variable score = 100.
    • Inside a function, create a local score = 50 and return it.
    • Print both values (inside and outside the function).

Part D: Global Keyword

  1. Write a global variable counter = 0.
    • Write a function increment() that uses global counter to add 1 each time it runs.
    • Call it multiple times and print counter.
    • Explain why this is not a good practice.

Part E: Better Design

  1. Rewrite the increment() function so that it takes a number as input and returns it increased by 1 (no globals).

item.title: Assignment 4.4
item.description:
Assignment 4.4: Errors and Exceptions

Prepare

  1. Review Lesson 4.4 slides.
  2. Revisit the Python Essentials section on exceptions.

Practice

Part A: Syntax vs. Runtime

  1. Write a line of code that causes a SyntaxError. (Don’t fix it yet!)
  2. Write code that causes a ValueError.
  3. Write code that causes an IndexError.

Part B: Observing Errors

  1. Run each program and record the error message Python gives you.
  2. Explain in your own words the difference between a syntax error and an exception.

Part C: Common Exceptions

  1. Write code that:
    • Divides 10 by 0 (ZeroDivisionError)
    • Converts "abc" into an integer (ValueError)
    • Accesses a key that doesn’t exist in a dictionary (KeyError)

Part D: Reflection

  1. Why do unhandled exceptions stop a program?
  2. Why do you think Python separates syntax errors from runtime exceptions?

item.title: Assignment 4.5
item.description:
Assignment 4.5: Handling Exceptions

Prepare

  1. Review Lesson 4.5 slides.
  2. Revisit the Python Essentials section on handling exceptions.

Practice

Part A: Basic Try/Except

  1. Write code that asks the user to enter a number and divides 100 by it.
    • Catch any error with a simple except: and print a message.

Part B: Specific Exceptions

  1. Improve your code to catch specific errors:
    • ValueError when the input isn’t a number
    • ZeroDivisionError when dividing by zero

Part C: Function with Exception Handling

  1. Write a function safe_divide(a, b) that returns the result of division, or a string error message if it fails.

Part D: More Practice

  1. Write a function to_int(s) that:
    • Converts a string to an integer
    • Returns the integer if successful
    • Returns the string "Error: not a number" if it fails

item.title: Assignment 4.6
item.description:
Assignment 4.6: Raising Exceptions

  1. Review Lesson 4.6 slides.
  2. Revisit the Python Essentials section on raising exceptions.

Part A: Simple Raise

  1. Write a function divide(a, b) that:
    • Raises a ZeroDivisionError if b is zero
    • Otherwise returns the result of a / b

Part B: Validating Input

  1. Write a function set_age(age) that:
    • Raises a ValueError if age is negative
    • Returns the age otherwise

Part C: Adding Messages

  1. Write code that checks if a number n is negative.
    • If so, raise a ValueError with the message: "Number cannot be negative"

Part D: Custom Function

  1. Write a function get_grade(score) that:
    • Raises a ValueError if the score is less than 0 or greater than 100
    • Returns the letter grade (A, B, C, D, F) otherwise

item.title: Assignment 4.7
item.description:
Assignment 4.7: Functions + Exceptions Together

  1. Review Lesson 4.7 slides.
  2. Revisit the Python Essentials section on combining functions with exceptions.

Part A: Safe Division

  1. Write a function safe_divide(a, b) that:
    • Returns the result of a / b
    • Returns the string "Error: Division by zero" if b is zero

Part B: Validating Input

  1. Write a function get_age(age) that:
    • Raises a ValueError if age is negative
    • Returns the age otherwise

Part C: Safe List Access

  1. Write a function get_item(lst, index) that:
    • Returns the item at the given index
    • Returns the string "Error: Index out of range" if the index is invalid

Part D: Custom Function

  1. Write a function read_number(prompt) that:
    • Asks the user for input
    • Tries to convert it to an integer
    • Returns the integer if valid
    • Returns the string "Error: not a number" if invalid

Submission

Submit your .py file with all code labeled clearly.

item.title: Assignment 4.7
item.description:
Unit 4 Review

Practice Problems

  1. Write a function triple_sum(a, b, c) that returns three numbers added together.
  2. Write a function largest(*nums) that returns the largest number passed in.
  3. Create a global variable x = 10. Inside a function, create a local variable also named x = 5. Print both values and explain what happens.
  4. Write a function safe_divide(a, b) that returns the result of division, or the string "Error: Division by zero" if b is 0.
  5. Write a function positive_only(n) that raises a ValueError if n is negative, otherwise returns n.
  6. Fix the following code:
def subtract(a, b):
    return a - c   # bug
  1. Write a function count_vowels(s) that returns the number of vowels in a string.
  2. Write a function reverse_list(lst) that returns a list in reverse order without using reversed().
  3. Write code that asks the user for a number and handles both ValueError and ZeroDivisionError if they try to divide 100 by it.
  4. Write a function student_info(**info) that accepts keyword arguments like name="Sam", age=16 and returns a formatted string.

Debugging Challenges

  1. Identify and fix the error:
my_list = [1, 2, 3]
print(my_list[5])
  1. Identify and fix the error:
value = int("ten")
  1. Identify and fix the error:
def greet(name):
    print("Hello" + age)

Reflection

  1. Identify one concept from Unit 4 you feel confident in and one concept you need to practice more.

Submission

Submit your .py file with solutions to the practice problems, debugging challenges, and your reflection answer.

item.title: Assignment 5.2
item.description:
Assignment 5.2: Hangman Setup

Goal

Create the first version of Hangman where the player guesses one letter at a time and sees their progress.

Instructions

  1. Choose a secret word (hard-code it in your program).
  2. Create a list of blanks (_) with the same length as the word.
  3. Ask the user to guess a letter.
  4. If the guessed letter is in the word, replace the blanks with that letter.
  5. Print the updated blanks so the user can see their progress.

Example Run

Word: _ _ _ _ _ _
Guess a letter: o
Word: _ _ _ _ o _

Challenge

  • Make it loop until the player has guessed the whole word.
  • Add a win message when the word is revealed.

Submission

Upload your .py file to Canvas.

item.title: Assignment 5.3
item.description:
Assignment 5.3: Hangman with Error Handling (Prepare)

Goal

Improve your Hangman game so that it can handle bad input gracefully.

Instructions

  1. Start with your Hangman code from last class.
  2. Add checks so the player can only enter one alphabetical character.
  3. If the input is invalid, print an error message and let the player try again.
  4. Continue the game as normal if the input is valid.

Example Run

Word: _ _ _ _ _ _
Guess a letter: 3
Invalid input! Please enter a single letter.
Guess a letter: py
Invalid input! Please enter a single letter.
Guess a letter: p
Word: p _ _ _ _ _

Challenge

  • Add a counter that shows how many invalid attempts the player has made.
  • Print a message if they exceed 3 invalid tries.

Submission

Upload your .py file to Canvas.

item.title: Assignment 5.4
item.description:
Assignment 5.4: Debugging Hangman (Rehearse)

Goal

Practice fixing broken Python code by identifying and correcting bugs in Hangman.

Instructions

  1. Download the provided buggy Hangman snippets from Canvas.
  2. For each snippet:
    • Run the code and note the error message (if any).
    • Identify what is wrong in the code.
    • Correct the error and show the fixed version.
  3. Answer the reflection questions at the end.

Example

Buggy Code:

if word[i] = guess:
    blanks[i] == guess

Error Message: SyntaxError: cannot assign to expression

item.title: Assignment 5.5
item.description:
Assignment 5.5: Mini-Challenges (Prepare)

Goal

Practice writing several small games in Python that use loops, conditionals, and random.

Instructions

  1. Complete at least two of the provided mini-challenges in class.
    • Guess the Word
    • Dice Roller
    • Coin Flip
  2. Write your own original mini-game (5–10 lines of code).
    • Must use at least one loop
    • Must use at least one conditional
  3. Submit all of your .py files to Canvas.

Example Run (Coin Flip)

Heads or Tails? Heads
Correct!

Challenge

  • Add scoring to your game (keep track of wins/losses).
  • Add replay ability with a loop.

Submission

Upload all .py files for this assignment to Canvas.

item.title: Assignment 5.6
item.description:
Assignment 5.6: Adventure Game Draft (Prepare)

Goal

Write the first draft of your own text-based adventure game.

Instructions

  1. Create a storyline with at least 5 decision points.
  2. Use if/elif/else statements to handle different choices.
  3. Your game must have at least 2 different endings.
  4. Add at least one “default” case if the player types something unexpected.

Example Run

You are in a forest. Do you climb a tree or follow the path? path
You walk down the path and reach a river.
Do you swim across or build a raft? raft
You build a raft and cross safely. You win!

Challenge

  • Add a secret “hidden choice” the player can type.
  • Write a fun or unexpected outcome for it.

Submission

Upload your .py file to Canvas.

item.title: Assignment 5.7
item.description:
Assignment 5.7: Adventure Game with Functions (Prepare)

Goal

Refactor your Adventure Game so it is organized into functions and safe for user input.

Instructions

  1. Start with your Adventure Game draft from Assignment 5.6.
  2. Break your game into at least 3 functions (e.g., intro, path1, path2).
  3. Use .lower() to make input case-insensitive.
  4. Add a clear message when the player types something invalid.

Example Run

You are in a cave. Do you go left or right? LEFT
You chose left!
You find treasure!

Challenge

  • Add a function for a “secret path” that players can only discover if they type the right word.
  • Make sure invalid input doesn’t crash the program.

Submission

Upload your .py file to Canvas.

item.title: Assignment 5.8
item.description:
Assignment 5.8: Group Adventure Game Checkpoint (Prepare)

Goal

Work as a team to combine your Adventure Games into one larger, working project.

Instructions

  1. Form a group of 2–3 students.
  2. Share your individual Adventure Game drafts.
  3. Combine them into a single Python file with a continuous storyline.
  4. Organize code with functions for different story paths.
  5. Make sure the game runs smoothly without crashing.

Example Group Plan

  • Student A: Intro + first choice
  • Student B: Left path storyline
  • Student C: Right path storyline

Challenge

  • Add at least one “secret path” that can only be discovered with a special input.
  • Use a loop to let the player restart the game without rerunning the program.

Submission

Upload your group’s .py file to Canvas.

item.title: Assignment 6.1
item.description:
Assignment 6.1: Data Mini-Projects – Introduction (Prepare)

Goal

Start working with a simple dataset and perform basic data analysis.

Instructions

  1. Download or create a simple dataset. It could be about:
    • Students’ scores
    • Movie ratings
    • Sports statistics
  2. Create a list of dictionaries to represent the data. Each dictionary should represent one entry (e.g., one student or one movie).
  3. Calculate the following:
    • The average value of a particular field (e.g., the average score or rating).
    • The highest and lowest value of that field.
  4. Print the results clearly.

Example Dataset (Students’ Scores)

students = [
    {'name': 'Alice', 'score': 90},
    {'name': 'Bob', 'score': 80},
    {'name': 'Charlie', 'score': 85}
]

Challenge

  • Add additional fields to your dataset (e.g., age, genre, etc.).
  • Perform a more advanced calculation, such as finding the median or filtering based on a condition (e.g., finding students with scores above 85).

Submission

Upload your .py file and the dataset (if external) to Canvas.

item.title: Assignment 6.2
item.description:
Assignment 6.2: Advanced Data Techniques (Prepare)

Goal

Practice working with complex datasets by filtering, sorting, and aggregating data. Visualize the results using matplotlib.

Instructions

  1. Download or create a dataset with at least 3 columns (e.g., names, ages, scores, etc.).
  2. Perform the following:
    • Filter the data to only include values that meet a condition (e.g., score > 85).
    • Sort the data by one column (e.g., by score or age).
    • Group the data by a specific field and calculate the average of another field (e.g., average score by age).
  3. Use matplotlib to create a bar chart to visualize one of your findings (e.g., student scores).
  4. Submit your .py file with the dataset and visualizations to Canvas.

Example Dataset

import pandas as pd

data = {
    'name': ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie', 'David'],
    'age': [25, 30, 35, 40],
    'score': [90, 80, 85, 95]
}

df = pd.DataFrame(data)

Challenge

  • Add a second dataset (e.g., age_group with corresponding score averages).
  • Perform more complex calculations (e.g., median, standard deviation).

Rubric

  • Dataset includes at least 3 columns (30%)
  • Filtering, sorting, and aggregation are correctly performed (40%)
  • Visualization is created with matplotlib (20%)
  • Code runs without errors (10%)

item.title: Assignment 6.4
item.description:
Assignment 6.4: Debugging Dataset Code (Rehearse)

Goal

Strengthen debugging skills by identifying and fixing common errors in Python code that works with datasets.

Instructions

  1. Download the provided buggy dataset scripts from Canvas.
  2. For each script:
    • Run the code and note the error message.
    • Identify the cause of the error (missing values, wrong data type, etc.).
    • Correct the code so it runs properly.
  3. Write a short explanation (2–3 sentences) for each bug and how you fixed it.

Example

Buggy Code:

item.title: Assignment 6.6
item.description:
Assignment 6.6: Dataset Project Proposal (Prepare)

Goal

Choose a dataset and outline your plan for analysis and visualization.

Instructions

  1. Select a dataset with at least 3 columns (e.g., name, category, score).
    • You may use a CSV from the internet or create your own small dataset.
  2. Write a short proposal answering these questions:
    • What dataset are you using?
    • What fields (columns) does it include?
    • What questions do you plan to answer with the data?
    • What kind of visualization(s) will you create?
  3. Submit a one-page proposal (text document or markdown) and your dataset file (CSV or .py with embedded data).

Challenge

  • Sketch your visualization on paper or in code.
  • Try loading your dataset into pandas and print the first few rows.

Rubric

  • Dataset chosen and included (30%)
  • Proposal clearly answers all questions (40%)
  • Plan includes at least one visualization (20%)
  • Submission is complete and well-organized (10%)

item.title: Assignment 6.7
item.description:
Assignment 6.7: Nested Data Practice (Prepare)

Goal

Practice working with nested data structures to extract and analyze information.

Instructions

  1. Create a nested data structure (list of dicts or dict of dicts) that fits your dataset theme.
    Example: A dictionary where each key is a student, and the value is another dictionary of subjects and scores.
  2. Write code that:
    • Prints one specific value from your nested structure
    • Loops through the structure to find the maximum value
    • Calculates the average of a numeric field across entries
  3. Submit your .py file to Canvas.

Example

grades = {
    "Alice": {"math": 90, "science": 85},
    "Bob": {"math": 70, "science": 88}
}

# Loop to find highest science score
highest = 0
for student in grades:
    if grades[student]["science"] > highest:
        highest = grades[student]["science"]

print("Highest science score:", highest)

Challenge

  • Add one more level of nesting (e.g., years, categories).
  • Write code that aggregates values across multiple levels.

Rubric

  • Creates valid nested data structure (30%)
  • Correctly accesses and prints specific values (20%)
  • Correctly finds a maximum and average using loops (30%)
  • Code runs without errors (20%)

item.title: Assignment 6.8
item.description:
Assignment 6.8: Data Debugging & Mini-Project (Rehearse)

Goal

Review Unit 6 skills by debugging code and completing a short data mini-project.

Instructions

  1. Download the provided buggy dataset scripts from Canvas.
  2. For each script:
    • Run the code and identify the error.
    • Fix the error and explain the cause.
  3. Then complete a short mini-project with your chosen dataset:
    • Clean the data (remove NaN, convert types, drop duplicates).
    • Perform at least one filtering and one sorting operation.
    • Calculate mean, median, and standard deviation for a numeric column.
    • Create one visualization using matplotlib.

Example Fix

Buggy Code:

item.title: Assignment 7.10
item.description:
Assignment 7.10: Work Day Checkpoint – Final Polish (Prepare)

Goal

Show progress on final polishing of your Creative Project.

Instructions

  1. Open your current project code.
  2. Review your program requirements:
    • User input
    • Loops and/or conditionals
    • Creativity and originality
  3. Debug any errors and make sure the program runs start-to-finish without crashing.
  4. Add comments to explain at least 3 major sections of your code.
  5. Improve the user experience:
    • Add clear instructions or menus
    • Fix spacing and formatting in your output
  6. Submit your updated .py file to Canvas.

Example Improvements

  • Added a welcome message: print("Welcome to my chatbot!")
  • Fixed spacing between outputs using "\n"
  • Added an instruction line for entering choices

Challenge

  • Add one “extra feature” that goes beyond the basic requirements (e.g., a hidden Easter egg, random surprise event, bonus round).

Rubric

  • Program runs start-to-finish without errors (40%)
  • Includes comments explaining major sections (20%)
  • User experience improved (instructions, spacing, clarity) (30%)
  • Bonus creativity/extra feature (10%)

item.title: Assignment 7.2
item.description:
Assignment 7.2: Random Story Generator (Prepare)

Goal

Create a Python program that generates silly random stories using lists and random.choice().

Instructions

  1. Import the random module.
  2. Create at least 3 lists of words (e.g., characters, places, items).
  3. Use random.choice() to select one word from each list.
  4. Combine the words into a story string using f-strings.
  5. Print the story.

Example Run

The pirate found a laser in the castle.

Challenge

  • Ask the user for their name and add it into the story.
  • Add at least 5 options per list to make the stories more varied.
  • Create 2 or more different story templates that the program can choose from.

Submission

Upload your .py file to Canvas.

item.title: Assignment 7.3
item.description:
Assignment 7.3: Silly Chatbot (Prepare)

Goal

Create a chatbot that uses if/elif/else to interact with the user.

Instructions

  1. Write a Python program that asks the user at least 3 questions.
  2. Provide at least 2 possible responses for each question using if/elif/else.
  3. Print the chatbot’s responses in a fun, silly style.

Example Run

What is your favorite color? blue
Blue! That’s my favorite too.

Do you like pizza? yes
Me too! Pineapple on pizza forever.

How are you feeling today? tired
Robots don’t sleep, but I understand.

Challenge

  • Add input validation (so if the user types something unexpected, the chatbot still responds).
  • Use lower() so answers aren’t case-sensitive.

Submission

Upload your .py file to Canvas.

item.title: Assignment 7.5
item.description:
Assignment 7.5: Creative Project Proposal (Prepare)

Goal

Write a proposal for your Unit 7 Capstone Project idea.

Instructions

  1. Brainstorm 2–3 possible project ideas.
  2. Choose your favorite and write a short proposal (half a page to one page).
  3. Your proposal should answer:
    • What is your project idea?
    • What will the program do?
    • What features will it include (loops, conditionals, user input, etc.)?
    • What will make it fun or unique?
  4. Submit your written proposal to Canvas.

Example Proposal (short version)

Idea: A random meal generator
Program: Asks the user what kind of food they like, then generates a random meal suggestion.
Features: Uses lists, random.choice, loops for multiple suggestions.
Unique: Can include silly or unrealistic meals like “spaghetti tacos.”

item.title: Assignment 7.6
item.description:
Assignment 7.6: Capstone Project Work Day Checkpoint (Prepare)

Goal

Show progress on your Creative Project by building the basic structure of your program.

Instructions

  1. Open your project proposal from Assignment 7.5.
  2. Begin coding the structure of your project:
    • Create variables, lists, or dictionaries you will need.
    • Write at least one function.
    • Add placeholder code (e.g., print("TODO: add game loop")).
  3. Make sure at least one feature of your program works by the end of class (e.g., a menu, one chatbot response, a random choice, or a loop).
  4. Save your progress and upload your .py file to Canvas.

Example

import random

def menu():
    print("Welcome to my random story generator!")
    choice = input("Press Enter to continue...")
    print("TODO: add story options here")

menu()

Challenge

  • Add user input and one working response.
  • Comment your code to explain what each part will do.

Rubric

  • Code includes project structure (30%)
  • At least one working feature implemented (40%)
  • Code is saved and uploaded (20%)
  • Bonus for creativity or extra detail (10%)

item.title: Assignment 7.7
item.description:
Assignment 7.7: Project Progress Checkpoint – Functions & Error Handling (Prepare)

Goal

Demonstrate progress on your Creative Project by adding functions and input safety.

Instructions

  1. Open your current project code.
  2. Add at least two functions that each handle a clear task (e.g., show_menu(), play_round(), make_choice()).
  3. Add input validation using one or more of:
    • .lower() / .strip() to normalize input
    • if/elif/else to check allowed options
    • try/except to catch ValueError when converting types
  4. Your program should:
    • Prompt the user for input
    • Handle unexpected input without crashing
    • Continue (or reprompt) until valid input is entered
  5. Comment your code to explain each new function’s purpose.
  6. Submit your updated .py file to Canvas.

Example Snippet

def ask_int(prompt):
    while True:
        try:
            return int(input(prompt))
        except ValueError:
            print("Please enter a whole number.")

level = ask_int("Choose difficulty (1-3): ")
print("Starting level:", level)

Checklist

  • Two new functions created and used
  • Input is validated and program does not crash
  • Clear comments for new functions
  • App runs end-to-end for a simple path

Rubric

  • Two functional, well-named functions added (40%)
  • Robust input handling (try/except, validation, reprompt) (40%)
  • Code clarity (comments, readable flow) (10%)
  • Runs without errors (10%)

item.title: Assignment 7.8
item.description:
Assignment 7.8: Project Checkpoint & Debugging (Prepare)

Goal

Demonstrate progress on your Creative Project and practice debugging strategies.

Instructions

  1. Open your current project code.
  2. Run your program and identify at least 2 bugs or issues (they may be logic errors, input problems, or missing features).
  3. Fix the bugs and test your program to confirm it runs correctly.
  4. Write a short explanation (3–4 sentences) describing:
    • The bugs you found
    • How you fixed them
    • What debugging strategy you used (print statements, error messages, etc.)
  5. Submit your updated .py file and your explanation to Canvas.

Example

Buggy Code:

item.title: Assignment 7.9
item.description:
Assignment 7.9: Peer Review & Reflection (Prepare)

Goal

Provide constructive feedback on a classmate’s project and reflect on feedback you receive.

Instructions

  1. Pair up with a classmate.
  2. Run their project and complete the Peer Review Form:
    • What works well?
    • What could be improved?
    • Any bugs or errors?
    • One new idea to try
  3. Share your feedback with your partner.
  4. Receive feedback on your own project.
  5. Write a short reflection (5–6 sentences) answering:
    • What feedback did you receive?
    • What change will you make to improve your project?
    • What feedback did you find most helpful?

Example Peer Review

Partner’s Project: Chatbot
What works well: Responses are funny and creative
What could be improved: Add input validation
Bugs/Errors: Crashes if user types a number instead of text
New Idea: Add a “random response” option

item.title: Assignmnent 3.8
item.description:
Assignment 3.8 – Working with 2D Lists

Objective

Learn how to create, access, and modify elements in 2D lists.

Part A: Creating and Accessing

  1. Create a 2D list called grid with 3 rows and 3 columns of numbers 1–9.
  2. Print the element in the second row, third column.

Part B: Modifying

  1. Start with: 
    board = [
    ["X", "O", "X"],
    [" ", "X", "O"],
    ["O", " ", " "]
]
  2. Change the top-left element to “O”.
  3. Change the bottom row to ["X", "X", "X"].

Part C: Looping

  1. Write code that prints each row of grid on one line.
  2. Write nested loops that print every element in grid separately.

Part D: Mini Challenge

Write a program that:

item.title: Code Testing Helper
item.description:
You can use this simple testing code on your assignments and programs to help you test your code more easily. Feel free to copy paste and modify as needed

def test_func(result, expected):
    assert result == expected, f"result:{result} expected:{expected}"

# this is just an example of a function to test
def full_name(first, last, last_first=False):
    if last_first:
        return f"{last}, {first}"
    return f"{first} {last}"


# cases is a list of test cases where each item in the list is a tuple (<result>, <expected>). Be sure to cover all required cases
cases = [
    (full_name("William", "Lapinel"), "William Lapinel"),
    (full_name("William", "Lapinel", last_first=True), "Lapinel, William"),
]
# loop over the cases and call test_func on each one
for result, expected in cases:
    test_func(result, expected)

item.title: Midterm Review
item.description:
Midterm Practice Problems (Units 1–4)

Unit 1: Basics, Variables, Booleans

  1. Write a program that stores your name in a variable and prints a greeting.

  2. Predict the output:

    x = True
y = False
print(x and not y)

  3. Convert the string "42" into an integer and add 8.

  4. What is the difference between = and ==? Give an example.

  5. Write code that checks if a number is both greater than 10 and even.

Unit 2: Loops

  1. Write a for loop that prints the numbers 1 through 10.

item.title: Mr. Lapinels Rules & Procedures
item.description:
Welcome!

About this course

This course is a 16-week, semester-long introduction to Python. Our main objective will be passing the Python Institute’s Certified Entry-Level Programmer (PCEP) certification.

We’ll take the PCEP exam soon after midterms. You’ll have 2 attempts, one on October 14th and another on October 17th.

Devices

You’ll be using the laptops I have in class. Personal devices are currently not authorized for use in class. You may use your personal devices for classwork outside of class, however.

item.title: Plan
item.description:
🗓️ Unit 7: Creative Python Projects

Dates: Nov 17 – Dec 12, 2025 (4 weeks, minus Nov 26–28 for Thanksgiving) Focus: Creative applications of Python — ASCII art, randomizers, chatbots, and capstone projects. Students will show off what they’ve learned.

Week 1 (Nov 17–21)

Mon Nov 17 – Lesson 7.1

  • Topic: ASCII Art Generators (loops + strings)
  • Assignment 7.1

Tue Nov 18 – Lesson 7.2

  • Topic: Story Randomizers (random.choice, lists)
  • Assignment 7.2

Wed Nov 19 – Lesson 7.3

item.title: Syllabus
item.description:
Python 1 Programming Course Outline

PCEP-30-02 Certified Entry-Level Python Programmer Aligned August 12 - December 18

Course Overview

This course introduces students to programming fundamentals using Python while preparing them for the PCEP-30-02 (Certified Entry-Level Python Programmer) certification exam. The curriculum follows the official PCEP exam syllabus, ensuring students master both practical programming skills and certification requirements. The course is structured into 8 units, with the first 4 units directly aligned with the four PCEP exam sections.

item.title: Teacher-made Final Exam Study Guide
item.description:
Teacher-Made Final Exam Study Guide

This guide reviews the key topics from Units 1–4 to help you prepare for the Final Exam.

Unit 1: Basics & Variables

  • print() displays output; input() collects input (always as a string).
  • Variable names:
    • Must start with a letter or _.
    • Cannot use keywords (e.g., class, def).
  • Data types:
    • int: whole numbers (42)
    • float: decimals (3.14)
    • str: text (“hello”)
    • bool: True or False
  • Operators:
    • + addition, - subtraction, * multiplication, / division
    • // floor division, % remainder, ** exponentiation
  • Comments use #.

Unit 2: Conditionals & Loops

  • if/elif/else for decision-making.
  • Logical operators:
    • and, or, not
  • Loops:
    • for i in range(n): runs n times.
    • while condition: runs until condition is false.
  • Loop controls:
    • break: stop loop early.
    • continue: skip to next iteration.
    • pass: placeholder.
  • range(start, stop, step) generates sequences.

Unit 3: Data Structures

  • List: ordered, mutable, [1,2,3]
    • append(), pop(), slicing list[1:3]
  • Tuple: ordered, immutable, (1,2,3)
  • Dictionary: key-value pairs, {"a":1, "b":2}
    • Access with dict["a"] → 1
    • KeyError if missing
  • Set: unique, unordered, {1,2,3}
  • Use len() to count items.
  • Membership: in keyword.

Unit 4: Functions & Exceptions

  • Define with def: 
    def greet(name):
    return "Hello " + name
  • Functions can have default parameters: def f(x=5)
  • Scope: variables inside functions are local.
  • Return value: if no return, function returns None.

Exceptions

  • try/except handles errors: 
    try:
    x = int("abc")
except ValueError:
    print("Invalid number")
  • else: runs if no error.
  • finally: always runs.
  • Common exceptions:
    • ValueError: invalid conversion
    • IndexError: list index out of range
    • KeyError: missing dictionary key
    • ZeroDivisionError: divide by zero
    • NameError: variable not defined

Practice Checklist

  • Can you:
    • Write a loop that prints numbers 1–10?
    • Create and access a dictionary?
    • Explain difference between list and tuple?
    • Write a function that takes a parameter and returns a result?
    • Handle invalid user input with try/except?

Tip: Review all quizzes and practice problems — the final exam is cumulative and covers everything above.

item.title: Unit 1: Computer Programming and Python Fundamentals
